2.text: Even to day is my complaint bitter: my stroke is heavier than my groaning.

3.text: Oh that I knew where I might find him! that I might come even to his seat!

4.text: I would order my cause before him, and fill my mouth with arguments.

5.text: I would know the words which he would answer me, and understand what he would say unto me.

6.text: Will he plead against me with his great power? No; but he would put strength in me.

7.text: There the righteous might dispute with him; so should I be delivered for ever from my judge.

8.text: Behold, I go forward, but he is not there; and backward, but I cannot perceive him:

9.text: On the left hand, where he doth work, but I cannot behold him: he hideth himself on the right hand, that I cannot see him:

10.text: But he knoweth the way that I take: when he hath tried me, I shall come forth as gold.

11.text: My foot hath held his steps, his way have I kept, and not declined.

12.text: Neither have I gone back from the commandment of his lips; I have esteemed the words of his mouth more than my necessary food.

13.text: But he is in one mind, and who can turn him? and what his soul desireth, even that he doeth.

14.text: For he performeth the thing that is appointed for me: and many such things are with him.

15.text: Therefore am I troubled at his presence: when I consider, I am afraid of him.

16.text: For God maketh my heart soft, and the Almighty troubleth me:

17.text: Because I was not cut off before the darkness, neither hath he covered the darkness from my face.
